response.answer_text: The word creative can mean many things to many people. I am going to post 1 essay that is by any stretch creative. I have then asked questions after the essay (and provided a lot of footnotes). Should you look at this essay as a template? No, but it should inspire you to try something that might be a bit quirky (or even not in good taste). And essay like the one I am including could doom the person who write it iif a certain reader found it offensive or not organized in a traditional way. The people I know who I trust about essays those who have written books on the subject) have found this essay compelling. I promise never to repent. I promise to electrify you. Me too you, she said. Creative is one thing, but you want to make sure you don’t do something entirely unexpected. Regardless of how “creative” your essay is, it still needs to answer the question being asked and tell the program you’re applying to what they want to know about you. I would do research on other students who have successfully matriculated to the programs you want to apply to and review their essays, if possible. First, DO NOT plagiarize other essays. What you want to look for is how the essays are written, meaning organization, topic, grammar, vocabulary, etc. Also, particular fields, schools, and programs come to expect a certain type of information presented in a certain way. The Internet is swimming in sites people post to about which program has what requirement as far as the essay goes. Do as much research on this as you can. Once you have all that information, pick a topic and get writing. The last thing I would advise is to place the emphasis of your writing process on editing over the actual writing; 80 : 20 editing to writing is a good rule of thumb. Honestly, if you don’t edit your essay at least 20 times, it won’t be worth the paper it’s printed on.

The question seems an odd one, if you think about it. By creative, most people mean different or original. Asking me to provide you a way to be different or original seems silly, since you are original, and I don’t know you. Look, nobody knows you, not really. Only you know you. Nobody else can provide you a way to be yourself. You have to be yourself, to accept that self, in order to be original and different. Your experiences are real. No one else has those experiences in just the way you do, no matter what anyone tells you. And those experiences, as you intimately experience them, are more important than the college admissions process. Focus on what’s meaningful to you; write about it honestly. That’s a good start.

I think parallelism is an excellent tool. Layer the structure so that it intertwines between two parallel universes. For example, let’s say you’re writing a 6 paragraph essay (1 intro, 4 body, 1 conclusion) about how you want to intertwine spirituality with science. Layer it with anecdotes from spirituality and science in the 4 body paragraphs. Weave them together with examples. For example, Jesus, scientific accounts of his life, Buddha, scientific accounts of his life. Ok that example wasn’t so good. OR…Transformers, p2-Michael Bay’s direction of the film, p3-The commercial aspects of it, P4-How Michael Bay’s direction of the film was interpreted by the actors, P5-How much the actors made. That example was a little bit too scatterbrained. I dunno, just work on it and see what happens. Just let go. Relax. Understand that it doesn’t really matter. And see what happens.

Not everyone is creative, per se. The other suggestion to intertwine two ideas is a good strategy. The important thing is to be authentic, not creative. Authenticity differs by the writer, so we can't tell you how to be authentic. Think about one or two things that are important to you. If they are two disparate qualities, that makes it easier to write something interesting. So if you are both a football player and a ballet dancer, that would pique the reader’s interest. If you don't have anything interesting to say, the problem isn't the essay. Spend some time thinking about what is important to you. What do you care about? What is your purpose in attending college? What do you want to do in the future? Be yourself. If that doesn't get you into a college, then find a college where you are a fit.

For writing a creative essay you need to have some clear concepts for writing an elegant essay. The particular topic for which you are writing the essay and whom it is addressed to makes a lot of difference in creativity of your essay. Draft your essay in a correct format and write all the contents without any error. The message conveyed should be clear.

Talk about something small that means a lot to you personally and then relate it to how it’s inspired you to do big things. In other words, take the concept of something small, like a personal item or an item that has impacted your life, and make it relate to how it’s inspired your ambitions, drives, and goals. Use lots of detail to convey your story to show how much something so minuscule has impacted you and how you can take that impact and use it to do good things in the world.
